response.answer_text: Very succinctly, “good singing technique” is probably best defined as maximum vocal power and beauty with minimal effort. By “effort” I’m talking about pressure on the vocal cords. Producing good, strong vocal sound (power) is going to have to come from somewhere. Most people (wrongly) do this by straining the vocal cords. This is an option, to be sure, but not in any way can I recommend it as a good one, not when you have a a whole body full of muscles attached to your breathing apparatus that can supply that power. Once you’ve properly engaged your body into producing the raw power, it really is just a matter of training your voice to manage how that power is directed. The analogy I like to use is that of a car: the voice is the transmission, not the engine. That’s your diaphragm (abdominal muscles). Many people use their intercostal (rib) muscles in their singing, just as they do in their regular breathing and speaking (you know, those two vocal enterprises that really don’t need any skill). But to really “throw” the voice against the back of a large hall, you’ve got to find a way to “drive” the tone. This isn’t done (healthfully) by straining the vocal cords; it’s done by driving the breath from deep in the body. I promise you, if you do this right, it will make substantial and notable difference. Back to the car analogy: most people “drive” their voices in first gear. By this I mean that they sing in one register, usually the chest register. When they get to high notes, they just push their voices harder. DUMB DUMB DUMB DUMB DUMB. That is NOT how the voice was designed, and just like driving a car in first gear all the time, it will bring your singing career to an early and spectacular end. The muscles in the larynx (voice box; our “transmission”) are designed to offer various “modes” (think “gears”) of operation to create differentials in how the breath power is used. Smooth transition between these modes of operation is a learned skill: it’s not easy, it usually takes a long time to master, but it will save your voice for the rest of your life. Once you know how to balance your voice (manage the “gear changes”) over the consistent breath (gradually press on the gas pedal), your technique will cause your voice to work much more efficiently, powerfully, and more easily managed—so you can pay attention to making art instead of just sound.

A lot of people will suggest lessons, practice, exercises and blah blah. I’ll go in the other direction. FIND A REASON TO SING. Too many singers think all they need is technique and they fail to cultivate heart and soul. I have heard many skilled and trained singers who bore me and all I hear is their technique. I’ve also heard untrained singers with many vocal flaws who inspire me. Why? Because they have something to sing about. Janis Joplin is one. Although, alcohol and drugs helped give her her confidence. Where can you find something to sing about? Go feed the hungry, clothe the naked, heal the sick, comfort the dying, visit the imprisoned, march in a protest, have a baby, find something that makes you angry, sad, happy, hopeful, inspired . . . then sing about it. That alone is worth more than five years of lessons. Most of the world’s greatest artists (not mere professionals) were people ostracized, lonely, abandoned, different, despised . . . they had something to sing about. It is often the least of us who become the best. When you have something to sing about, you can let your technique go and just communicate your deepest self. If you sing for fame and fortune, you most likely will never find it. But, know that it is in you and waiting to burst out. Chances are you have technique and lessons standing in your way, stifling your Kaddosh or mountain top experience. Kaddosh (From an article I wrote) So, the first part of the Canon is the Kaddosh. It is the opportunity for you to enter into the holy. The cleric says "Lift up your hearts" and our response is "We lift them up unto the Lord." But do we? This little segment of prayer goes by very fast and there isn't much time to "enter into the Holy." When you enter a baseball stadium there are a few thousand people there and it is noisy. You can probably feel the excitement and energy of the crowd around and within you almost immediately. Energy begets energy and soon you are unmitigated in your participation. You can easily let go and get caught up in the excitement. Just like when Isaiah entered into heaven in his dream, there were thousands of angels there singing. What is holy and sacred to you that gives you a special feeling or a high? Was it being present at the birth of your child? Scaling the summit of some great mountain and taking in the view? Could it be holding the hand of a loved one as they pass away? Is it like watching the sunset with someone you adore? Whatever it is, you need to know it and practice it so when your cleric invites you to lift your heart into a holy place, you can do it. To further augment this action of your mind, heart and soul, consider lifting your hands a little as you say "We lift them up unto the Lord."

I agree with Bob Huber. Listening to many genres and singers gives you an idea of what you like. Also you learn how to sing by listening (and watching performances). And I personally think many of the today’s singers (and some older ones) are more about the glitz, dances and dancing and the exciting music than about singing. If you can, get someone who can sing to listen to you and give you some tips. Proper singing classes is better but short of money and/or time may not allow this. Careful with this as not everyone has a good ear to hear your issues and many musicians (like I was when I was younger) are overly critical and may not give constructive criticism. Practice… practice… practice. But don’t strain your voice. If you can’t hit the note, don’t try too hard. Ask a vocal trainer to help you with those. A strained voice can become a damaged voice if you are not careful. Practice the use of your “stomach” to breathe. Practice to ensure you don’t exhaust your breathe before the end of the line (of music). Perform. First in front of your friends and people who have a ear for music. Ask for constructive criticism - and don’t get angry with them. Even if you have no interest in performing, still let others comment on your singing technique. If you are, after this perform. Volunteer to perform in small events or karaoke nights. I have an issue with karaoke - most singers push up their reverb to the maximum, making their voice sound better than it is. If you want to learn how it sounds turn the reverb to a minimum so that you can hear how it really sounds. I think you should record yourself - but beware - you may not like how the recording sounds. I didn’t. In fact, I hated how my voice sounded when it was played back to me. All the best in your journey on the way to learning the joys of singing!

Well this topic question is being changed but I will answer it for you. Comes near/dear to my heart. First realize that - that nervousness is something I LOVE! It shows vulnerability and man does it emote. Do not be so quick to get rid of it IMHO. Here’s what you do… Find a place where no one else can hear you. (animals are a good sounding board by the way) Then find your MOST favorite song ever. Work on one part of the song that fits your voice the best. Try to listening to yourself by cupping you hands on your ears… ala the BeeGees. Find a place with hard surfaces/tiles so you can better hear the echo. spend time getting that one passage down having fun and experimenting with the inflections. Next try to sing it in your 3 voices. with a finger on your chest bone sing so only that bones is vibrating real good… then try to dial into the notes the best you can (this is the lower register - see if you like it) Next do the same with your throat - so that vibrates… (middle register) and finally your head/temple (high register). Learn about MASK singing (ala Diana Ross) squashing/flattening your mouth/lips pushing the air upwards towards your nose/nasal cavity. Next get a cheap mic like a $20 AKG 8000dm. (used is ok) and an interface like a used focusrite solo or behringer (about $50) - and download a free PC recording program - Audacity or a pro one like Reaper Cockos Native Reaper. Record your voice… and see where the notes you are singing… with all the different type voices… then use a graphic analyzer and zero in on what you like - try adding echo reverb or double-track-delay to hone in more. As you find a vocal sound that YOU like - start emulating that and keep practicing. Pursue getting a part of the song where you like it. Then start tweaking the arrangement to better FIT your voice. If there is no song that really fits you voice THEN write one! it is a fun journey anyone can sing… get comfortable so that you like what you do… you are inspired by what you are working on. If it still does not sound good enough for you try different genres (rap/jazz/talk singing/pop/rock/metal etc) - add some instruments to compliment you voice - try autotune - try other mics try karaoki - there are endless ways to reach your goal - I believe everybody can sing - just find your sweetspot / wheelhouse… and work with that. The destination is the journey soon you will have something you are proud of… go for it! tc

Keep in mind that not everyone has a naturally “pretty” singing voice. But, everyone can improve their singing (and their health) by remembering these things: • Breathe with your diaphragm. Your shoulders should not be moving when you inhale this way. Instead of your chest, your stomach should be moving up and down. Practice this for a few minutes and take long deep breaths. • Find out your vocal range and type. This will help you know what you are more comfortable with. For men: bass sings low, baritone sings middle, tenor sings high. For women and kids: alto sings low, mezzo sings middle, soprano sings high. • Sing more! Sing every single day so you get more practice. Make sure you warm up so you don't strain your voice. Sing scales, sing DEH songs, whatever floats your boat! • Don't try too hard or too much. Many people, usually females, love to sing high notes. In my school choir, all the girls are very competitive about how the sopranos are “better” than the mezzos or altos. This is a common misconception. Don't strain your voice trying to hit high notes. Try some low notes for a change. You may not be a woman, but remember: it takes a real woman to sing like a man! • Become active! Join your town’s choir. Audition for a musical. Even karaoke night can be considered experience. I have been in 11 musicals. I participate in my college’s drama club, choir and advanced ensemble. You won't get anywhere without taking the first step. • Last but not least, I want to talk about voice lessons. I'm no voice coach, but I can tell you right now, my voice lessons changed me for life. Music is so much more than it was to me before. I now have a larger range. I now know how to breathe correctly. There are so many precious things you can learn from voice lessons. Hopefully this was helpful! Never Stop Singing! (:

However, for the majority of my personal singing career, I have not had much vocal training. Despite my experience and the fact that singing is one of my deepest passions that doesn’t mean nobody has ever said I personally sucked, I’ve been told that I do indeed suck. When I first started out singing in a small class band many years ago. A woman told me I ruined one of her favourite songs ever, this was the only time someone has ever criticised my singing voice though. The ultimate takeaway is that it doesn’t matter how good you are people will always hate your voice especially if the song you sing is one of their own personal favourites. My best advice for you is to listen to songs that you like, and sing along with them. Listen to how the singer sings them and try your best to replicate what you here, this takes years of practice and there may be many new vocal techniques you learn along the way that might take some time to acquire but it’s like learning any instrument. It just takes practice, as far as weather or not you are a bad singer, I would need to here what your voice sounds like in order to make a judgement. However, you do not have to be Freddie Mercury in order to be a good singer, James Hetfield and Dave Mustaine are two of the most successful vocalists in metal music but they do not have what one would consider amazing singing voices. This has been my personal experience anyway, I hope this helps.

Learn proper techniques and what not to do.  It is preferable to learn from a teacher who has trained ears and will listen to you and give you immediate feedback, to help you discern what you are doing that is good for your voice and ways you may be damaging your voice. Besides taking care of yourself (sleep well, eat right, get exercise so you are reasonably aerobically fit), there are specific things you can do to protect your voice.  Don't yell or scream.  Keep hydrated, don't wait until you're thirsty to drink; by that time you are already dehydrated.  Don't over-practice.  Rest when your voice needs it.  For a beginner, half an hour, even split in 15 minute sessions or less, up to a maximum of an hour and a half, is more than enough.  The goal is not to practice more, but to practice correctly.   Your voice is a musical instrument that uses lots of tiny and big muscles, many of which you are unaware of.  To sing well requires vocal coordinations of some tiny muscles around your vocal folds, moving the (pharyngeal) flap that you can't see that makes you sound nasal or not, lifting your soft palate to make room for airflow, and very good control over the breath.  For that, you need to relax and let the air in, and squeeze that air all out at an even pace even after you've expelled most of it.  To develop the muscle memory of doing it correctly, your body needs proper practice, repetition. I've written plenty of posts on singing tips - and there are others on Quora with experience with singing and know more than I do.  I would recommend that you read and check out the information available online, and find a really good teacher.  Learn the science behind the voice and the terminology.  Focus on hearing the difference in the voices of others - good vocal teachers should be excellent at producing the sounds for you so that you can discern the differences when they do it, and then they can give you exercises to trick your voice into also doing the right things.  With time, you can train your ears to also discern the difference.  As an example, I have always had a tendency toward a nasal voice.  You should easily hear the difference between pinching your nose and speaking, vs not pinching your nose, but there is also a way to maneuver the pharyngeal flap to lessen nasal sounding vowels, even though some consonants require some nasal sound.  I can now much more easily discern when I'm doing one and not the other, and I can move that flap at will now that I am 1. aware of it and 2. have practice controlling it.  Just as you can train other muscles of your body, you can train the muscles that alter your voice. Recognize that you have your own voice.  There is no need to mimic others' vocal instruments.  You will have a natural timbre, tone, and it's the best thing to learn to love your own voice, both in your head, and recorded (which may not sound like yourself at first, until you are used to it).  You may not be able to sing all kinds of music, be as loud as you'd like, or sing styles that don't suit your voice.  Sure, you can karaoke, transpose if you want, or just sing along anyway, and sometimes, that's okay. But, for regular singing and performing, don't sing things that are not intended for you.  I love to sing songs by male voices, but I'm a mezzo-soprano with a maximum possible range of D3-E6, and it's not all usable; that's only what I can trill. I can sing an F3/E3 but it's at the breathy end.  The D3 is a hit or miss even if I'm warmed up, it's not really usable.  I'm probably okay up to a B5.  C6, maybe D6, if I'm warmed up and having a good vocal day.  E6 needed for Phantom of the Opera? :( nope.  No way, never.  All this means that I can sing Phantom of the Opera but not that last note, and when I sing songs sung by kpop tenors, I am doomed to have to transpose for anything lower than an E3/D3, even on a good day.  I can, however, enjoy self-karaoke to most of the rest of such songs, and just blow air at those low notes. ;)  It gets too much into vocal fry, so my teacher has recommend I limit it.  Instead, I look for songs in a female range that I can practice with, and just don't sing the notes that aren't meant for me when I sing along with pop tenors. Don't worry about perfection.  Music is all about expression.  If you get your message across and feel it emanate from you, that's more important.  Things like pitch and rhythm are critical if you're performing, but it's okay to mess up when you're learning.  Don't take it too seriously, and don't screw around with your voice, either.  You'll honor yourself best by singing things that make you happy and that suit you.

I will talk practically first, then come at the question from a different angle. Practically first. If you feel that your voice could improve, then you need to do exercises to improve the voice. Everyone can make their singing voice better. What you need to develop is the support system around your voice. Singing comes from your core and the more control you have of that, the more control you have over your voice. This can then influence the texture, tone and power of your voice. Your singing will feel more enjoyable because you will be able to do more. Vocal exercises do not take long to do and if you look on google you will find some there. They key is consistency. The more you practice the exercises, the better your voice will be. Alan Watts the english philosopher says that the only reason that someone should do anything is because they enjoy doing it. Now wanting to improve is fine, but doing it on the back of a judgement about yourself ‘I am bad, i must improve’ is not the best place to come from. Singing is a learned skill and everyone can improve with the help of a well-trained instructor. You can learn to hear and then sing the right note, to sustain notes longer, to sing louder, to expand your range, to avoid hissing and other habits that annoy listeners. Singing is a physical skill like throwing a football, hitting a ping pong ball or dancing. Learning a physical skill takes practice, repetition and feedback from someone who already knows the skill—you can’t learn to sing just by reading a book. Like other physical skills, there are specific physical techniques needed to get the most from your voice. Have you ever seen someone throw a ball awkwardly, the ball flying off in an unpredictable direction without much force and then seen another person hurl a missile precisely targeted? The second person isn’t necessarily stronger, but they do have every muscle in their body working in coordination. That second person wasn’t born knowing how to throw precisely—they learned a technique and practiced it until it was second nature. Singing is similar. The method for improvement is practice guided by an experienced voice teacher. An experienced teacher is important—we could play ping pong for years and not improve much because we will not spontaneously adopt the techniques needed to hit with great force and spin. But add a skilled teacher and our ping pong can transform in only weeks. A skilled singing instructor can also help you make major improvements quickly. Currently your singing is a work in progress so while you practice you won’t be perfect. To improve, you must practice even though you are imperfect and to do that, you must tolerate your imperfection. Improvement starts with not judging your skills. When judging (and finding yourself lacking), you get discouraged and afraid to try new things. My suggestions are: Accept you are a work in progress and that is OK.Find an experienced voice teacher and follow their instructions; do every exercise they suggest daily.Perform a 1-month experiment to see how much you can improve. Record yourself now, then after 1-month of lessons and diligent practice, record the same song. then take an objective look at how much your singing has changed.You are not anyone else, so what some other person can do doesn’t matter. What matters is whether you are getting 20% of your best or 90%. Take some lessons, do some practice and maintain tunnel vision on improving your technique. You may be shocked how much better you become. Good luck and best wishes!

There are several ways to train the voice.: Get a good voice coach. He/She will give you some exercises to be done every day.Sing in a choir with a good voice coach and practice at home with the same exercises. But note: This is good for the choir-sound, probably not  or a growing solo voice.For me as a professional it is possible to invent my one exercises on the base of experiences with my voice teachers.In my opinion it is necessary to separate warming up,  learning a new technique and studying a piece of music. Each of this subjects are essential. Here I can only give some hints, because the relation to a good and matching voice trainer is very important to succeed. Warming up  Do some exercises to combine your breathing-in  with the posture-muscles of your body. This will have the effect of a natural support. Activating the breathing -in-muscles is necessary. After every breath sing immediately a short phrase in a third or a fifth range. and keep going. To get an effect every exercise has to be repeated at least 3 times.Combine  forming the vowels first with breathing in + phrase then with breathing out +phrase.Use rounded vowels first (o,u). They support the resonance.High tones  need more open vowels than lower ones.Beginners have to start with  middle-high notes singing the scales downwards to prevent  pitch-regulation  with using air pressure. If you want to reach higher notes, you have to get softer and softer, because for the chords it is very similar to sing high notes and piano notes.Keep going! Don't control too much! Just do the exercise! Learning the technique is completely different: Guidance of a trainer is needed.The trainer is not only for giving orders to you but to guide your concentration and your attention to the important aspects. Be aware of what your body is actually doing. Hear what effect the exercise has on  your sound.Never start with complicated tasks. For example: Getting louder or softer is an intermediate skill. So it is with high and loud phrases with text.Awareness -> Hearing -> Controlling ->Awareness...Studying the music is completely different as well: Never mix up warm-up and studying the musicWhen you want to start with a piece warming up has to be done. Be certain about the style in which the music is written. Some styles need a special technique.Even most professional musicians need help learning the score with a répétiteur. Alert: If you had a good training, don't get confused with some of  his advices . Try to find out what he/she wants to achieve and  use the technique, you have learned.A  répétiteur is not a coach. He only can introduce you to the music score. Everything else is your business including reading your part.

Question asked: How can I have a more powerful singing voice? I assume it is not already as powerful as it can be. Of course there are some physiological fearures that benefit some people when it comes to voice (power). We have to have healthy lungs and well functioning mucous membranes. But the size of the lungs/vital capacity has little to say. We should have an erect posture and a good balance, our breathing should be full - including the whole torso - and make us wider at the waist. Take a breath of well being and contentment. This also opens up your resonance spaces of your throat (as well as lowers the larynx/voice box). It is paramount to keep the resonance spaces open - which begins with the full breath and is supported by larger muscles at waist level. Tune your vowels by adjusting your organs of articulation (tongue, jaw, lips etc.) for the optimal timbre - in accordance with the pitch. With training this tuning becomes automatically established at onset of the tone - thus being gentler on the vocal folds. No more compression should be produced than needed. Don't push, force or strain the voice in persuit of loud sound - we have to follow its nature as an acoustic wind instrument - and obey its resonances. We have to be familiar with the registers and how to negotiate them to achieve access to our entire range. All this technical training should be done with a well experienced singing teacher. Best of luck.

These are some that I use even though I am not in a band anymore I still want to keep my voice in good shape; 1. Tongue Twisters At first glance, practicing tongue twisters may not seem like an especially useful exercise, but they can help to improve enunciation of song lyrics. Practice the tongue twisters below until you get the hang of them: Peter Piper picked a peck of pickled peppersA peck of pickled peppers Peter Piper pickedIf Peter Piper picked a peck of pickled peppersWhere’s the peck of pickled peppers Peter Piper picked? You know New York, you need New York, you know you need unique New York How much wood would a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood?He would chuck, he would, as much as he could, and chuck as much woodAs a woodchuck would if a woodchuck could chuck wood. Around the rugged rock the ragged rascal ran. 2. Laugh— From the Gut It’s no joke; singing from the throat can damage your voice and produce a harsh or nasally sound. Instead, you should aim to sing from your diaphragm, or from your gut. Adopting this singing technique will also help you hit those tough high notes, increasing your vocal range. One great way to learn how to do this is by laughing (seriously!). Let out a series of Ha-Ha-Ha’s, ensuring the sound comes from deep within your gut—the louder the better! This will strengthen your abdominal muscles, improving your ability to sing with proper support. 3. Ear Training When you play a given chord on a guitar or piano that hasn’t been tuned, the sound produced is like nails on a chalkboard. Listening to someone sing out of tune is similarly cringe worthy. Fortunately, ear training exercises can help us recognize when we’re singing out of tune. All you need to begin ear training is some basic knowledge of musical scales. A scale is a sequence of notes that fall within the same pitch. For example, the C major scale is C–D–E–F–G–A–B–[C] (with the second C in brackets to indicate that it is an octave higher than the first C). Start by playing a C-chord on guitar or piano in an octave within your vocal range (i.e. that you can easily hit without straining your voice), listening carefully. AT THE A END OF THE ANSWER WE HAVE A AMAZING OFFER!!!! 1. The “Instant Vocal Fix” This is a quick trick that makes you sound better instantly. Say A-E-I-O-U (watch your jaw movement in the mirror). Did your jaw close on any of the vowels? Chances are your jaw closed on the E and the U – and most likely on others too, if not all of them. Take your first two fingers and pull your jaw down 2 inches (or even better – use a plastic bottle cap or a cork (wine) to prop your jaw open). And speak the vowels again. And repeat again (we’re trying to re-program muscle memory – so the more the better). Now sing the vowels on one pitch. A-E-I-O-U. Your goal is to keep your jaw open (long not wide) without closing for all of your vowels. Repeat until you can do it. Now sing a phrase of one of your songs – and make sure your jaw opens to the same position on all of your vowels. You have to practice this a bunch before it becomes natural – but the more you do, the sooner this new movement is programmed into your muscle memory. And, you might be one of those lucky ones who notice the improvement in the sound right away (it will sound louder and more resonant with less vocal strain). If you don’t – don’t sweat it – you will. It just takes a little practice. (You might have some unwanted tension in your neck, jaw and throat muscles – try loosening them up and try it again.) The next time you perform open your jaw more on your vowels — it’s a quick trick that makes you sound better instantly! 2. “Think down” for High Notes The next time you sing an ascending vocal scale or you sing a high note, try thinking of the way an elevator works. A heavy weight is attached to a pulley and as the weight pulls down, the elevator actually goes up to the higher floors. So, the highest floor is reached when the weight is the heaviest. Similarly, you should think down for your high notes or think of adding weight (resistance) to your highest notes. 3. More Power without Strain Who doesn’t want more power without strain? This is a simple technique to apply and a bit easier than the one above. All you have to do is to keep your chin pointed slightly down and your pectorals slightly flexed (well sometimes it’s a lot flexed) when you go for more power. Most singers reach forward or lift their chin up to sing with more power. While it may temporarily work, it causes vocal problems. Tipping your chin down not only works better and saves your voice – it actually SOUNDS better! Stand in front of the good ‘ol mirror. Sing an Ah scale up and down in one phrase (1-2-3-4-3-2-1). Press your chin slightly in (point your chin towards the floor) — usually only 1” or so. Don’t let your head bob up as you raise the pitch. Keep it firmly in place. Go all the way up the scale of your voice keeping this position. Notice how your chin wants to move up as you raise your pitch. Keep it planted. This will give you more power and control and eliminate strain. Practice it until it becomes natural! 4. How to Get Natural Vibrato In Your Voice Here’s a quick tip to get your vibrato working. Stand in front of a mirror; press on your chest with both hands, then, raise your chest higher than normal. Take a breath in and then exhale, but don’t drop your chest. Sing one note and hold it as long as possible with your chest raised. Press on your chest halfway through the note (press kind of hard and raise your chest to meet the pressure). Relax the back of your neck and keep your jaw open as you’re singing “ahhh.” Imagine the air spinning around in your mouth while keeping your chin tucked down a bit and your chest raised. Keep in mind, overuse of vibrato is not a good thing in contemporary singing (pop, rock, and R&B). At the same time, no vibrato is also not a good thing. Unless you’re really going for breathy or nasal as a stylistic choice, somewhere right in between the two is a perfect balance. HearFones® allow you to really hear yourself and work on your tone at medium volumes. Best: study with a teacher with academic credentials. But if you cannot, see the introductory text below. ABCs of Singing There’s an easy way to think about voice culture: the ABCs of Singing. The same things apply to the speaking voice. A is for Alignment. For singing, stand with feet a few cm. apart, NOT exactly parallel, with weight slightly forward on the balls of the feet. Feel a sense of energy in your feet and legs. Keep knees flexible, not tight. Raise your hands far, far above your head, and then allow them to descend and rest easily at your sides. Let your back be straight, even if you are seated for Indian music. Imagine there is a silver thread from the base of your spine out the top of your head that allows your body to float up, up, up. Allow the ribs to expand like an opening umbrella. It is never static or tight, but flexible and dynamic. As you practice, come back to these points, and refresh your alignment/posture. B is for Breathing. Exercise: “Breathe through a straw,” inhale through puckered lips. Immediately hiss out LOUDLY, with great energy from the middle of the body (abdominal area). Feel how this increases energy in the breath. Maintain alignment - don’t allow the upper body to collapse as you exhale. Return to this exercise a few times as you practice. As you sing, breathe LOW in the body, and imagine you have a tire inner tube around your middle; fill it up and lean into it. Always think “up.” C is for Coordination. Importantly, as you go higher, let the voice get lighter and brighter - don’t use a lot of pressure. But, allow the ribs to rise a little, and allow the energy from the middle of the body to increase a little. Don’t yell or scream - instead, slightly increase breath energy and expand your posture to make the sound a little higher or louder. Exercise: easily repeat one note with a breath between then sustain and crescendo diminuendo - get louder and softer [ a, a, a, a———- ] . Repeat the exercise on higher note, several times. This is a very basic start. To really improve your singing voice, get a teacher with academic credentials in voice teaching.

So experiment a little with vocal range, singing do-re-mi at a variety of pitches until you get to the point where you’re straining to reach the upper registers. Then STOP. You don’t want to damage your voice permanently. Then see how well you can reproduce your favorite kind of music. Can you sing it back note for note? If not, work with it until you can. Then I would find a chorus of some sort. Church choirs are the easiest to find, and not too awfully picky. See what the director can teach you, in terms of sight-reading and choral diction (hint: you don’t pronounce sung words the same way as spoken words). Community choruses are actually quite a bit pickier, in terms of their expectations of singers, but if the idea of a church choir really frosts you, give the community chorus a shot. They might be willing to work with you. The idea is not just to improve your singing, but to improve your overall awareness of vocal music. Choral singing teaches you to focus your attention on your own part, while still listening to the other parts for things like cues (when to come in on your part). The emphasis on choral diction teaches you to appreciate precision in the spoken word as well as the sung word. And of course, the fun of singing with other like-minded persons is unbeatable.

I’m going to be a bit of a black sheep. DO copy others, but NOT when you perform, unless you’re supposed to be imitating someone. Trying to sing like your favorite singers (without pushing in an attempt to go beyond your range) is a fun way to improve your own style and uniqueness. I guarantee you about 99.9999% of professional singers have done this despite what their teachers told them. Now, onto the actual technique. Making it sound powerful (and protecting your voice from damage). Get a full body mirror and stand to the side. You want to put one hand on your chest, and one on your stomach. Puff out your chest as much as you can without being goofy. Drop your shoulders too. Now inhale. Only your bottom hand should move. Exhale. Only your bottom hand should move. Repeat. Making it sound pretty. Yawn. Or the next time you yawn, pay attention to what the roof of your mouth does. Try to recreate that. If that is difficult, open your mouth two fingers wide, keep your fingers in there, and try saying “Yada, yada, yada” without biting your fingers off. You feel that pressure in the back of your mouth? Do that every time you sing. It’ll help you stay on pitch and it will open up your resonance. Making it sound prettier. Say sing, now say sinnnnnnngggggggg. The “ng” sound is the key to opening up the nasal cavity. Sing a note on “ng” and feel your face with your hand, you should be letting air go through your nose, not blocking it off from your nose. You should feel vibrations in your face, at least in your nose. Try and keep this vibration in your face even when you aren’t singing “ng”. Well, that about wraps it up. Anyone else?

As a singer and a musician who has been taught to sing and taught others to sing, here are my top tips: Breathe correctly. Think of the air bypassing your lungs and getting pulled down into your abdomen. If your stomach expands when you breathe in, you’re doing it correctly. This helps to support the notes and gives you a nice, full sound.When learning a song, look at the notes. This seems like a no-brainer, but it’s not something singers always do. I once had a young student who was really struggling with a solo. She also played piano, so I knew she could read music. I told her to think of her voice like a musical instrument, and to read the notes as she sang. The change was almost instantaneous. That one tip helped her tremendously, and she was easily able to hit notes she’d struggled with before.Hear the next note in your head before you sing it. This one kind of goes along with #2, but it is a little trickier to master. But if you can do it, it really helps. It physiologically primes your vocal chords to sing the next note in tune.Once you know the song, feel it. As you’re learning a song, it’s very important to focus on technique and precision, but once you’ve practiced it and you know it, let expression take over. Let those crescendos and decrescendos come, let your voice crack— take the music out of the drivers seat and let your emotions do the talking. An imperfect solo sung with feeling will beat a perfectly sung emotionless solo every single time.

When you breathe, make sure you are taking air from your diaphragm instead of your chest. This means when you breathe in, your abdomen will expand instead of your chest. When you sing, you will push down on the diaphragm when you ascend a scale and release when you come back down the scale.Supporting your voice with the diaphragm is one of the keys to singing. To practice, place a hand on your stomach and inhale through your nose. Your abdomen should expand and jut out when you breathe in. Your chest should not move out or up. As you exhale, push down and contract the abdominal muscles. It should feel like doing a sit up. Repeat until this is natural when you are singing.3. Open your vowels: One quick way to improve your singing is to open your vowels. This is called open throat technique. To achieve this, start by saying "ah" or "uh." Elongate your mouth without widening it. You want to separate your tongue from your soft palette and keep them separated while you sing. Your tongue should be against your bottom jaw. This gives you better quality. Try saying A-E-I-O-U. Your jaw should not close on any of those. If you can't keep your jaw down, use your fingers to pull it down. Keep repeating the vowels until you can say them with your mouth open.Sing the vowels. Keep the jaw open while you sing them like you did while saying them. Then sing a phrase and open the jaw when you sing each vowel.This will probably take some practice to achieve, but it will help improve the quality of your singing.By doing this you can start to grow your voice.4. It is important to identify your sound and not try to sound like anyone else, learn to love your instrument. There are several aspects of the voice that can change the color and the beauty of the sound, the timber, brightness, raspiness and color.  Timber. besides your natural timbre, some vibrato and added support on sustained tones will make the voice richer. Try to vocalise on a single note with a clear vowel while slowly increasing and diminishing the tone. It is important that you breath deeply to support the sound.  Raspiness. listen to some trumpet players until you are able to hear the change in sound based on if any air is "leaking".Think about this with your vocal chords, if the sound is escaping your voice will sound raspy.  It is important to work with someone that could help you clean up the sound of your voice by keeping your vocal chords closed around the sound and providing just the right air support. Brightness. darker sounds are more classic, brighter sounds are often less trained. The shape of your vowels and your posture will influence your sound, the position of your chin and shape of your mouth. Good luck

You are - and always will be - your own worst critic. So keep in mind, you may not be as bad as you think you are. But if you are as bad as you think you are, and you are serious about getting better, the first step should be lessons from a vocal coach. Check their references and testimonials from former students. If you don’t want to pay for lessons, you can join a community or church choir. They will take you, and might help you improve. My tips for getting better on your own: Ensure you support your tone. Breathe deep, and when you sing, your diaphragm (abdominal muscles that push the air out) should be contracted and solid; not to force the air out, but to steady the airflow. A solid foundation will always improve the quality, for both vocal and wind instruments. Yes, your singing voice is an instrument, just like a trumpet, saxophone, or flute. Treat it as such: Warm up before practicing/performing. Sing long tones to practice holding pitches. Practice scales, intervals, etudes. Work the fundamentals, polish them. Musicians call it “woodshed-ing”, and it pays off. Good luck!

To make your voice sound better for singing, there are several ways that you can do, which include as follows:  Learn the correct breathing technique from the diaphragm and not the shallow one from the chest. This will allow you to have better support for your pitch as well as a good tone quality. Never place your voice on the throat while singing. This will not only affect your tone quality but also ruin your vocal cords in the long run due to excessive unnecessary strain. Do not sing songs that are way beyond your vocal range if you have not had the adequate technique to do so yet. If you have to, either replace the key or change the arrangement to fit your voice altogether. Do not do Michael Bolton or Whitney Houston if you have not learnt the required technique to sing their songs, which are often very physically challenging. Drink plenty of water because hydrating your vocal cords is extremely important. However, try to avoid cold water before any important performances such as a concert or a big gig since it can tense up your vocal cord muscles a little. Know the lyrics that you are singing well. In this way, you will be able to relate to them more and will not sound like your average karaoke singer.

Breath with your diaphragm, pulling and pushing your lungs from below your stomach. Once you’ve got that down, practice circular breathing by inhaling through your nostrils as you exhale from your mouth. You might not master this, but practicing improves your all around breathing skills. Practice making the loudest sound you can using the least breath; this will beef up your chords. For higher notes, try broadcasting through your nose as well, and avoid tilting your head backwards. This is a good cheat, but it takes a heavy toll on your chords. If you write your own lyrics, constantly speak them aloud. You want to flow: meter, cadence, phrasing. Watch for accents or consonants that hitch or stop in a line, and look for alternatives. Having a thesaurus at hand is a good idea, and some formal study of poetry is even better. Reciting Shakespeare is incredibly helpful too; that iambic pentameter is fucking brilliant. You don’t even need to know what the words mean as long as you pronounce them correctly. That old English is actually much easier to understand when you hear it in context. If you’re covering someone else’s material, try doing an impersonation while you’re learning the words, then switch to your natural voice. If you haven’t fully developed it yet, try impersonating someone who sounds totally different than the original singer. If your plan is to be a front(wo)man, unencumbered by an instrument, keep your visual appeal in mind. You don’t necessarily have to dance per se, but you should try to incorporate some movement into your performance. This will in turn require practicing such movement, as it will affect your breathing and delivery. I did it for twenty years, post-punk-metal-rock & roll hollering on key sorta style. I started when I was 15 (playing live and all that) and being self-taught amidst pubescent was okay, since it actually altered my physical shape (great big mouth, the torso of a 6’2” man on the legs of a 5’8” one) and made breathing & such second nature. Any older and some amount of formal training would be prudent, I believe. Oh yeah, no amount of practice can prepare you for what happens in a recording studio. Unless of course that’s where you practice! I won’t offer up advice on that, since I always kinda hated it and never felt like it was quite right in the end. That’s when you find out things like your big-ass boot lips are incapable of making a ‘P’ or a ‘B’ sound without ‘popping’, which spikes the level and blurs the immediately following syllables. Hope I’ve shaken some tasty acorns from my tree of knowledge, and happy hollering!

Preparation (‘building the vocal instrument’): vocal technique needs to be optimised by practicing efficiently, preferably under instruction from a reputable, effective singing teacher/vocal coach to know what & how to practice with the view to developing a robust, agile, responsive instrument. [1] A great singer also needs to keenly understand how music works, how the singing role fits in the larger music contexts they’ll be operating in and to develop creativity, musical taste & finesse. Performance (‘playing the vocal instrument’): singing & performing regularly, preferably in a range of contexts for versatility, builds skill & craft over time. I would also add that it’s important to keep the reasons why we sing at the forefront of our minds. The singers with the greatest impact & longevity are those who seek/sought to be true to themselves, to share something honest & substantial, to uplift & inspire and not simply serve the ego. Being a singer isn’t about having the best voice. It’s about having the voice suited to the material you’re singing. When you get better at singing you gain much better control over your voice and breath allowing you to improve your range and tone. This can help to increase your vocal range upwards when repeated over time, and can strengthen your voice. If you’re looking to expand your vocal range downwards, do the same, but start in the middle-high section of your range and work backwards, i.e. 8, 8–7–8, 8–7–6–7–8 etc. Like before, stop at 1, then lower the starting note. *I can attach a link to an example of this if needed.*

My initial advice: Learn vocal therapy techniques to keep your voice in good shape, especially if you are going to be imitating your favorite singers. Resonant voice placement techniques and other gentle vocal exercises can keep your voice strengthened and in good shape, even before you go to release your first note. Some lip trills, and some gentle humming are great to start with.  Push up on either side of your cheeks with your fingers, and feel your lips get looser and release tension. This will allow you to relax your larynx. Now just hum lightly while allowing the air to make your lips bubble in a b-b-b-b-b-b-b-b sound. Take this up and down in pitch once you get used to it. That’s a good first step in having a healthier voice, as well as sounding better. If you have a piano, you should do some trills and try to match pitch with the piano, as that’ll help your pitch. If you’re gonna imitate your favorite singers, remember not to push too hard. Imitation is good to learn new stylistic techniques, but what works in a healthy way for Ariana Grande might not work amazingly for you. If you have any more questions, feel free to send em’ over.

To be honest, the quickest way is by taking lessons from a professional voice teacher. I was only able to do those because we had one that visited my school to give lessons for cheap, they are normally very expensive. But if you can’t or don’t want to pay for that, then the best way to improve on your own time is to work on relaxing your voice and controlling your breath. When I say relaxing your voice I mean releasing tension in the muscles of your neck, throat, shoulders, and face while you sing, and breath control refers mainly to breathing with your diaphragm. Proper breathing for singers involves breathing deeply and feeling your diaphragm inflate your chest cavity, without heaving up your shoulders the way many people do when they breathe. These things can be difficult to do for a beginner who can’t always tell the difference, so one way you can help with this is by actually making different recordings of yourself singing and/or looking in the mirror while you practice and try to improve your technique. This can also help with your pitch-sense, which is most easily improved by simply practicing a lot and learning to better “feel” being right on the pitch.

The simplest, lowest-barrier way to get better at singing is to join a choir. Even choirs with directors who aren’t trained in vocal technique are going to provide feedback in the form of other voices, regular practice, and the opportunity to hear good singers. A skilled director will teach you everything from how to warm up your voice, to how to read music, to how to control and blend your voice with others. If you’re already in a choir and want to improve, there are many options. One option is to take voice lessons. Another is to practice ear training or learn to read music by studying another instrument such as piano. Additionally, breath control is generally considered to be the foundation of singing, so learning a skill like yoga or meditation can be useful.

The answer is, yes! Not everyone will be a Pavarotti, of course, but everyone can learn to sing better than they presently do. Here’s the logic behind – answer these questions: Do you have vocal cords?Are you able to make sound with your vocal cords? If you answered yes to the two above questions, then you can sing. Right? Well, maybe. If you are truly tone deaf, then chances are you can’t sing. Amusia, the technical term for tone deafness, is a perceptual problem. Someone who is tone deaf is unable to carry a simple tune or pick out differences in pitch. But does that mean if you can’t hear or match slight variations in pitch then you are tone deaf? No, certainly not! Scientists are still in disagreement where to draw the dividing line between a lack of training or even exposure to music and Amusia. So if you are able to very basically distinguish high pitches from lower ones you are probably not tone deaf. The same goes for being born deaf – if you can’t hear then you probably can’t sing (although there is research out there that suggests this is changing). Practice makes perfect so keep practicing to sing better and better.

Then I inhale through my nose and release on the exhale through my teeth like making an “ssss” sound slowly and with resistance, for about up to 30 seconds on the out breath. I do at least 10 of these a day. Also, I do a glide from low to high and high to low on lip rolls and tongue trills (rolling my lips and then my tongue from a low tone to a high tone and then stretching from high to low) Here are a stack of positions (consonant and vowel stacks) you can try by singing the in a row on a low note and then repeating the words in a row going higher to the next note (do this with all the stacks): Bah, Buh, Beh, Bee, Boo, Bum Gah, Guh, Geh, Gee, Goo, Gum Nah, Nuh, Neh, Nee, New, Num Mah, Muh, Meh, Mee, Moo, Mum Zach, Zuh, Zeb, Zee, Zeb, Zum I hope my share was understandable and you were able to give it a try. After the warmups, try singing some of your favorite songs. Nyla
